passages.name: g7
passages.content:
Four weeks later we arrive in the small town of Penu at the shores of Lkae Titticaca: ten days on a fast ship, the rest i a series of coaches. Both groups have kept to themselves, most of the time. Mr. Jones is travelling with us, and his polite flirting is the only unusual occurance during that part of our expeditionn.

Well, Mr. Jones is a gentleman of marriageable age -some thirty years old- and Marcella was a debutante. For the time being I AM a debutante. Therefore some flirting is only polite: as long as the debutante is careful and the gentleman polite nothing else happens. I doubt that Mr. Jones really knows what he is flirting with, but since he is as witty as he is polite I amuse myself with the little social games of humans. 
Whether Sir Edward, Parker and Mendoza in the other coach have a nice journey we do not know. 
[Image: laket]
Lake Titticaca is a marvel of it's own, but we are only at it's shore to gear up for the next leg of our journey: the King's roads end here (for us, at least), and we will travel onwards with mules. 

Sir William adresses our group after arrival: "I will procced to the town commander. Sir Edward, I would like you to come along. We need permissions and we do better to annoucne ourselves. This is a border town in a time of civil war. 
Mr. Jones, please check with the hotel -or coaching inn- whether they have rooms for us. Alyce, the maid, will prepare the room for Miss Marston where Alyce will also be staying. 
Miss Marston will accomapny her brother. He is going to order provisions and buy some mules." 

Sir Edwards nods: "Mendozza is with me, Parker..." Parker grunts: "I will keep the young gentles company and stop Mr. Marston from being cheated by storeowners in a way that endangers all of us." 
Parker and Mr. Marcellus Marston have not become dear friends.

passages.name: g6
passages.content:
When the gentlemen have lit their cigars -a new invention, from these very lands- Sir Edward leans back: "I am bringing myself, Parker and Mendoza. As well as the diary of Enrico de Aburrido, a Spanish conquistadotr and the only soldier that made it back from an ...interesting place... that I want to explore. Who and what do you bring to the table, Sir William?" 
[Image: cigar]
Sir William puffs at his cigar: "I am bringing myself, Miller, my son -Mr. Marcellus Marston- and my daughter, Miss Marston, to the table. As well as the funds for this exploration. I have invited Mr. Jones to join us. 
My children speak Spanish and Queche, the language of the locals. My son is a gentleman with the usual skills and competences. Both WILL join us, just like you will, Sir Edward. It would be rude of me to question your health, and rude of anyone else to question the fitness of my part of the group. We will also bring a maid along for Miss Marston." 

He turns to Mr. Jones: "Sir Edward has come into ownership of a diary by a conquistador whose unit was destroyed after finding an old temple with lots of gold. The temple has great historical value, the gold great monetary value. The enemies that have beset the Spaniards -no insult meant, Mendoza- must surely be dead by now. 
The area of interest is at the border of the Peruvian Viceroyalty: near the Lake Titicaca. On the Eastern shore of that lake is the border to Bolivia. A former Spanish colony that has declared themselves independant from the mother nation. Something we are painfully familiar with because of the more northern separetists that have broken from Britain. 
In such a region my diplomatic status -and some good weapons- can be expected to be of great value.
Are you interested in joining this expedition, Mr. Jones?" 

To no ones surprise, Mr. Jones is willing. No one really believes that this is the first time Sir William has told him about this, after all. To everyone's surprise Sir Edward does not mind Mr. Marston an

passages.name: g5
passages.content:
[Image: dinner]Since I am the only woman I play the lady of the house: Sir William introduces everyone to me. 
"These gentlemen are Sir Edward, Mr. Jones and, of course your brother. Dining with us tonight are Parker, Miller and Mendoza. Mr. Jones, please keep my duaghter company with her brother. Sir Edward, please sit with me. Parker, for tonight you can sit with Sir Edward and me. Miller and Mendoza, you are seated at the middle of the table." 

All quite daring and untraditional, but in a moderate way: if there is a moderate way to break tradition, Sir William will find it. 

[Image: dinnerarrangements]

I can make smalltalk like the lady of the house or eat in silence like a shy debutante. Miller and Mendozza do not partake in polite conversation: they are servants. 

Parker thinks that he is a gentleman, Sir William, Sir Edward, Mr. Jones and Mr. Marston (my twin) ARE gentlemen. 

After dinner the servants clear the table, and Sir Williams passes the gentlemen and Parker a cigar and a brandy.
Time to talk.

passages.name: g4
passages.content:
I may hae been wrong about my twin being asexual: when Marcella is the male twin, Marcellus uses my body for sex with some enthusiasm. I did have a lesson scheduled with one of the gentle whores that specialize in teaching young gentlemen the basics of siring sons (or making love, if they are any talented). Marcellus takes that lesson, and while the happy little whore kisses him on the cheek afterwards and calls him "shy" that is more than I would have expected from Marcella. 

Her body -that I am using now- has to remain virginal until marriage, of course. Weird, but that is how it is. My own sex drive -in a human body- is not difficult to handle: even though I had to call in a lot of favours from the Goat In The Woods to get Lady Marston pregnant, and the Goat In The Wood is all for fertility. 

While my twin sister had sex in my body, I did callisthenics in hers. The balance is off: her reproductive orgeans are internal while a male has external ones. But the human females have udders: all that is a lot to bear, and I NEED do to these callishenic for any resemblance of body control. 

Now we are going to dinner, washed up as is the pivilege of the ruling classes and dressed with the help of a happy and discreet whore (in case of Marcellus) and the maid, Alyce: in case of me trying to put Marcella's clothes on her body. 

[Image: fashion]VERY drafty: if one wants to wear clothes, and humans do, this is ...peculiar. Shoes -alwas good- and SOCKS. Knee-high, bound with a garter over the knees. Then NOTHING to cover that weird bush of human women. A short underdress called chemise, a knee length underskirt over that and the dress over the underdress: but if I grab the hems of the skirts I can pull blank from my thighs to my hips. 

Marcellus has girdled a spanish sword and a pistol. Well, she has training with a pistol: Sir William was open-minded about that. I have also given her some fencing lessons -this body is not utterly untrained- but Marcellus really should no

passages.name: g3
passages.content:
Sir WIlliams looks deeply unhappy and may be about to say something that is reall harmful at this point: his society teaches them that human men and women are basically utterly different in mental capability, willpower and strength. Many of their gentlemen do not mistreat  women (especially ladies) in their own point of view: they just assume that a lady has no capacity other than looking pretty and having babies. 

I tap a finger to our breakfasttable: "Sex is not nexessarily the hard border that you may think it is, Sir William. But neither is the life of a gentleman as easy and fun as you seem to think, Marcella. May I offer a suggestion?" 

My twin nods: it is easy to charm her since I have been protecting her for eighteen years now and she knows it, deep in her soul. Sir William shrugs and nods: he usually listens to all offers first, then he decides. He is a gentleman and a diplomat, after all. 

I tunr to Marcella: "Annergret knew the spell to switch minds with another human being. Specifically: a man. Her version of that spell is bloody and ineffective, but that is all of her 'art'. Therefore I am assuming that you have come here to make a scene, and when the stupid men are excited: cast that spell. Putting YOU into MY body and ME into YOUR body. 
Annegret's spell does not work that way: none of her spells work without blood and pain. 
But I know several versions -closer to the real magic- and can use one of these to switch us for a couple of months. For that time you will be in THIS body..." -I point at myself- "...and I will be in your body."
I smile at Sir William: "That happens to be the time that you will be on that archeological expedition that you have mentioned at breakfast. I am still coming, but now BOTH of your children are. A sort of family excursion, so to speak. In the backwaters of the land: if any social gaffe happens, no one will know. I understand that the final discussion about that expedition is tonight: Marcella and I can switch bodies f

passages.name: g2
passages.content:
Marcella, my twin, points the grey book at me, accusingly: "Annegret speaks of you as a cold hearted snake." 

I nod: "She has called me that to my face. But she also believed that the Horned Man hated her passionately and was hunting her down. Either there IS a Horned Man -the Hunter of the Wild Hunt- and he does not care about Annagret, or he does not exist and she wa dellusional. One cannot both be the archenemy of the Master of the Hunt and die peacefully of old age. Annegret was wrong about a lot of things." 

Sir William shrugs: "I do not know anything about the Horned Hunter or witches. I am a gentleman who got help in a delicate, urgent and stressful manner from another gentleman. How is none of my business. Your mother took a deep look into that world beyond a gentleman's perview, and she has taught me some spells. That I do not use, Marcella. Magic is secret for a reason: it disrupts human society. Keep your knowledge and your power secret." 
He points at me: "If you really need a reason for that beyond basic manners and goodwill: this is the learned gentleman that helped us. 
The price that WE paid for YOU was your mother having twins: one for us and one that was a rejuvenated learned gentleman. I do not know what price HE has paid, but I assume it was substantial. 
By the way: your dowry is ALL of my possessons. His inheritage is what were his possessions before our deal. 
Therefore regarding your brother you should keep some things in mind: you would not exist without his help. He paid a lot to make this happen and has never been anything but a polite and helpful ...businesspartner and, lately: son. You are richer than your mother was because you inherit her dowry and my means. AND: I can ensorcel you. I cannot ensorcel HIM. What do you think happens if you try to fight him?" 

I smile at her: "Witchery is much about gut feelings. So let me ask you a questions: imagine you walk alone from here to the harbour. Do you feel safe? Now imagine that WE, you a

passages.name: g1
passages.content:
My twin sister puts a notebook, maybe a diary, on the breakfast table where Sir WIlliam, our father, and I are talking . 
She frowns: "I want my birthright." 
Sir Williams motions her to sit and takes the booklet, I get up and pull a chair for my twin sister and pour her a cup of coffee: if in the Spanish colonies do like a Spaniard. The tea here is lousy, the coffee is very good. 

[Image: grimoire]I sit down and take the booklet from Sir William, who has leaved through it. I take a look : 'Diary of Annegret Bernhard, Maid, Wet-Nurse and Confidant'. I raise an eyebrow: "Is this the diary ...and grimoire.... Annegret, our wetnurse? This here looks like a ...spell to curse your enemies." 

My fair twin grabs the grey book of Anagret the Witch: "I KNOW THE TRUTH! You cannot distract me with a smear campaign against the witness, evil one! I claim my birthright that you have stolen!" 

Sir Williams sighs and tells her ...no: he ensorcels her: "SIT DOWN AND LISTEN." His eyes glow, one of the side effects of that spell. Marcella sits and listens: my dear twin may have found a book with the rants, recipes and spells of a self proclaimed with, but she is no great witch or wizard herself. Yet. 
Our father looks at me, with glowing eyes, and tries to ensorcel me: "TELL HER." 

I raise an eebrow: "William. Really." 

Sir William looks at Marcella: "That is basically all in short. But since you are not really well informed, here is the slightly longer form: your mother and I could not have children. All science failed us. I was accepting that, thinking about adoption. Your mother was NOT accepting, and she was as headstrong as she was beautiful and -sometimes- kind. We tried less reputable physicians and, soon, some self-proclaimed 'witches' and cultists. 
Hedge witches exist in every other country village in England, and some of them are real. Annegret Bernhard was one of them, and she had had a falling out some former friends. Very dramatic, all that. But in turn for us getti

passages.name: masters
passages.content:
Later. 

Miss Marston is only guessing. 

For those in the know: there is a Dunwich in England, too: East Essex. A coastal town, to no one's surprose. With lots of good fishing but very rude and ugly people. 
[Image: mortals]
The Andes, the Rockies and the Mimalaye are among the mountain rangers on earth where rare minerals can by mined: not with temporary human technology, of course. It would also help if one could, well: fly. 
The East India Company is sending expeditions into the Humalaya, too: of course. Sometimes they meet the locals.

No one really pays attention to Parker or Miller, unlike Miss Merston -sorry: Donna Fontana- who was watched by everyone when she got banged on the brothel table.

Back to a Peruvian temple ruin.

passages.name: g9
passages.content:
The shopkeeper agrees to have our provisions ready tomorrow morning. Marcells asks him to send us a list with the provisions to the hotel this evening so that the senorita -I smile charmingly- can take a look and see whether she needs something extra. The shopkeeper smiles knowingly and agrees to do that, too.

Back in the street Parker stops us: "What the hell do you think you are doing, kid?" 

Marcellus frowns, and starts to move forward. 

I snap my fan open between them and tell them: "We can kill each other in the countryside if we ever make it there." 
I snap my fan closed and smile. I tell them in a low, not carrying voice: "Step back NOW, both of you. Or the locals will come to call and ask questions about what we are doing here. Isn't that a secret, and aren't we keeping a low profile rather than fighting in the streets?" 
I turn to Parker: "I assmume that you are less than happy with our visit at the shop. Do you care to tell us why?"

Parker scoffs: "You are buying blind what he gives you. You do not even have a shopping list to check whether you get what you did not care to order item per item. He will overcharge you for things that we never get, and what we get will be mildwewed waste that he was about to throw away." 

Marcellus raises an eyebrow: "I see what you mean. But there some facts that you are not paying attention to. 
First of all this is the ONLY shop that sells provisions, just like the mule seller that we are heading to next is the ONLY seller in town. They can sell us what they want to sell us anyhow. We need to buy, right? 
Second we ARE getting a list. Tonight at the hotel. We can go over that: you can if you know about high mountain travel. 
I am hoping that Miller knows about this: he has been fighting in their mountains over in the old lands in the Spanish-French Wars. 
Third of all: I am using a different technique than you do. You, I guess, bully people. That does not work if a trader has a monopoly and we are foreigners in a town

passages.name: g8
passages.content:
[Image: shopping]I step between Marcellus and Parker when Marcellus enters the shop. Parker and I look each other in the eyes for a moment, then I take a step backwards and enter the store. Parker follows us. 

In the store Marcellus smiles at the shopkeeper: "/¡Buenas días, señor!"

The shopkeeper stands upright and say: "¡Buenas días, señor!
¡¡La señora!!"

I smile and nod. Marcellus approaches the corner: "Estoy buscando comprar provisiones para nueve personas. Mi padre, Caballero William Marston y Burrows, dirige una expedición académica a las montañas cercanas."
I tranlate: "My brother said: I am looking to buy provisions for nine persons. My father, Sir William, is leading a scholarly expedition into the nearby mountains."

Marcellus smiles politely: "Confío en que pueda proporcionarnos lo que necesitamos, señor."
I tranlate: "My brother said: I trust that you can provide us with what we need, sir."

The shopkeeper stands straight and nods when Marcellus treats him with the respect that any men in this land demands, belted knight to lowly servant.

Marcellus smiles and puts a handful of silver coins n the table: "Preferiría pagar en monedas de plata, si eso es aceptable, señor."
I tranlate: "My brother said: I would prefer to pay in silver coins, if that is acceptable, sir."

Silver coins are, to the best of our knowledge, still in use also in the lost Spanish colonies.

passages.name: g32
passages.content:
A week later we make camp in a small valley, deep in the Andes. They set up camp like very nervous veterans in enemy territory, but the dragoons off duty greatly enjoy the company of the whores. Alyce and the six village whores suffer a lot, and the former waitress is not getting a special treatment any longer. Other than me: like every night the teniente keeps me for himself. That does NOT mean that I do not have to spread my legs, though. every night the tenente rides me hard. 
[Image: lted]
In the morning the teniente and the padre talk with the British: "Beyond that pass is the temple that we are looking for. We will set up camp here, tighten ranks and go in with everyoman but the camp guards." 

The padre nods: "Let me be abundantly clear: either there is a whole heap of old stones, and we are all fools to be here. Or there is a very real, very dangerous evil in there. You have to decide no whether you are with us: or not. If you are with us, you will be treated like gentlemen prisoners in times of a bandit attack. An attack by bandits that are NOT allied to you, gentlemen." 

I take the teniente's arm off my arse: "Give them the last rites." They stare at me. I shrug: "Give the village whores the last rites before you 'tighten ranks', padre. They belief in that, even if you may not." 

Marcellus sneers: "Do you want to get annointed, too? When they shoot all the whores with lead instead of semen? Or do you still hope that they will spare you and only kill the other whores?" 
I shrug: Whatever.

passages.name: g30
passages.content:
The teniente is sitting at the table with me on his lap. Sir Edward and Parker sit at the second side, Sir William, Mr. Jones and Marcellus at the third side. 

The teniente fondles my swollen, naked breasts and looks at Sir Edward and Sir William: "Let us -as the British say- cut the crap. I know that you have made a deal with these bandits." He squeezes my boobs, hard: in anger, I guess: it hurts. "I dispise the so-called rebels, make no mistake. But these here are no rebels. They are bandits, and they have been bandits in these backlands for years now. Thank you for you help catching them, gentlemen." 

He leans back, pulling me with him and starts to play with my erect nipples: "But while I really like the price that you have been paying the bandits to let you pass: why did you throw your daughter to the wolves, sir? Because there is no denying that this little whore is the twin sister of your son and heir. The fine gentleman that watched when his sister was deflowered in public on a brothel table." 

Marcellus frowns, but Sir William puts a hand on his shoulder: "A matter of inheritance. Miss Marston stood to inherit something that will go to my son now that she is Ashley the Whore rather than Miss Marston. The plan was to let the bandits have two posh whores in turn of letting us pass without further ado." He shrugs: "Getting rid of Miss Marston has worked just fine. Unless you marry her, teniente, she will not inherit anything as a fallen woman. IF you want to marry her you have my blessing, of course. I am not giving a whore any dowry, of course.
But how did you find out about the bandits' plans?" 

Marcellus sneers and kisses my hand. Sir Edward, Parker and Mendoza could not care less.  Mr. Jones, Miller and Alyce look angry. Now I know who my enemies are, but I am still dripping seed from my abused womanhood.

passages.name: g33
passages.content:
While they are shooting the village whores the tenient walks me and Alyce to the side with a couple of dragoons and the padre. Sir William tags along to watch.

When we are more or less alone, the teniente turns to me: "I am a soldier. An officer. I kill poeple for a living. I have sworn to serve: not by getting shot to pieces, but by trying to win. That little French bastard blew us to parts. Us and our doctirne of noble warfare. Pragmatism is the word, so I have become prarmatic, like many of my fellow young officers." 
He kisses my hand: "I do not rue the death of the village whores, or laying a trap for these bandits and shooting them up in their own trap. That is necessary. But my mother would not like that I have made you my whore." 

I smile: "I do not like that, either."

He nods: "There are two kinds of women that are no virgins: whores and wives. You can never be a virgin again, little whore. But you CAN become a wife. I am told that you have an interesting dowry. Your father has thrown you to the wolves for that. He has also given me his blessings to marry you, little whore.
So here is a propostion, while I am cleanig camp: marry me. Then you are a wife, no whore: and I am much richer than I was. If you do, I do not have to shoot you and your bridesmaid. If you do not, we will burry two more whores." 

[Image: ring]I blink. Sir William opens his mouth, and the teniente put his pistol into Sir WIlliam's mouth. His gun pistol. Not the one he is putting into me every night. 

I look around: the dragoons that accompany us are carrying shovels. I guess I either get married or Alyce and I get burried. This will also thwart Sir William, and most women are married for sex and for their dowry. 

Sir William signs some papers, the padre does his thing, and the teniente puts on old ring on my finger: a family heirloom. The moment the ring is on my finger I faint.

passages.name: Parker
passages.content:
[Image: Parker 2]Parker is a big brute. Not a gentleman, not even a nouveau riche, but a street fighter with enough brains to become something between a foreman and an independant contractor for the East Incia Company.

The East India Company is still as powerful as the King and the parliament in Britain. They are no longer more powerful than the King and the parliament combined, and the East India Company resents that. They DID have more soldiers than the king at one time not long ago, after all. But lately they are loosing ground in Britain and -rumour has it- in India. 

Parker is some six feet five tall, big and a hardened street fighter. Marcellus really needs to stay away from him: the guy is dangerous. 

He also thinks that he is the only real man here, and the only one with a mind for business. Some people think that Parker is a 'white supremacist' because he treats the locals badly. But in fact he just hates them as much as us: Paker is no racist. He hates everyone.

passages.name: g35
passages.content:
[Image: rapier]   
We arm ourselves, take what equipment we may need and can carry, and walk to the pass with an escort of dragoons, led by the sargento: "We have lost half of our men -lost and destroyed the bodies- but we have also destroyed some twenty or so of these madmen. One cannot keep precise count in this kind of fight, Donna Fontana. That has visible reduced our attackers. There are -in our estimate- half a dozen of less of them left: that we have seen. Good luck: and I hope that you manage to safe the teniente ...and your family." He salutes. 

Interesting. He pretends to respect my, but he does not. He is not struggling with the idea of his teniente marrying a very used woman. He is ...amused, not angry... when he adresses me as 'Donna Fontana'. His care for the teniente is real, though: as is his complete lack of care for everyone else. 

We walk down into the valley, and when we are out of hearing I stop. "Parker, Miller: you have seen these 'madmen' in combat. How do they fight? Why is the sagento afraid and the padre confused?" 

Miller shrugs: "They look like humans -all of them are Spanish, wearing old conquistador uniforms if anything- and none of them is human. Their heads open at the crown and unfold into ...three maws that look like a cheese grater with hooked teeth as grates, for lack of better description. These three ...maws... wrap around limps -or a head- and when they pull back they leave nothing but the bone. They can be destroyed, but only when they are burnt they are really dead. Otherwise their bodes start to rebuild while one watches." 

I frown: "Well, I need to see one of these in action. Here is our tactic: If we get jumped by one or two of them, Parker and I engage it or them in close combat while Miller prepares the blackpowder to burn them. If we are getting overron by three or more, the two of you drop to the floor and cover. Covering your heads, especially your eyes, is a good idea." I draw the rapier that the sargento has gi

passages.name: g37
passages.content:
[Image: rapier]
They are taking this in stride, as if they had already knewn about the stark reality behind human  delusions. Interesting, but not in a good sense. Humans -trueblooded ones- do not accept this as easily. They simply cannot do that. Marcellus is a human being, and he -she, whatever- snapped when she or he realized that there is magic. 

I sigh: "Not to be rude, but may I assume that you represent a consortium with mining interests in the Americas ...and the Himalaya, in the borderlands with India?" Parker nods. 

I turn to Miller: "Your mother is from Dunwich, I assume." Miller nods, somewhat surprised. So he does not know yet. Huh. He does not have bulging eyes and a sore throat: but not all of them do. 

I shrug. "Let us proceed. We ALL need to stop this. Not only for our own individual survival but also to protect the interests of your masters." 

Things being what they are, I let my hair down some, so to speak: we head to the ossarium first. The Inca used to sacrifice body fluid to the gods. Mostly blood. The remains of the donors were collected in side rooms for exactly the purpose that I am applying them to: I raise the bones from the dead. Well: those that are still intact and can be raised. 
I am, among my people, especially gifted in that art: necromancy.

passages.name: g36
passages.content:
[Image: rapier]
We are getting jumped by one of the servant creatures. Parker and I hack it to pieces, Miller sets it ablaze. Impressivee. They are both as good as I was hoping. 

The servant creature is also impressive. "Interesting. The basis is a Spanish conquistador. Heavily modified by that worm in his chest." I point at the white slome in the buring body where the heart is in human bodies. "Burning really well and smelling like ...burning human fat." 

I raise an eyebrow: "If someone was crossing humans with giant death worms, this would be the result. With a little extra: changing existing bodies -like the dead conquistadores- like this is beyond a normal paraste. That requires ...power." 

I sigh: "Educated guess, but let us assume there is a powerful -like nearly divine powerful- being with some absurd weirdness imprisoned in that temple. That ...being... is kept there by some wards that are very, very old. And -since this is Peru, once the Incea Empire and before that something else entirely- these wards are made from gold. The most durable metal available in these mountains. 
Sometime -about two centuries ago- a band of conquistadores came here, massacred the guards if there were any left and started prying off the gold. 
Whatever dwells down there reached out: and voila, human-sized maggots hunting for human fat. That same being probably also reached out to somenone else and offered a ...deal instead: because the maggotmen are not really able to break the rest of the wards. The one who took that deal  would be..." 

Parker snorts: "Mendoza." 
Miller shakes his head: "Sir Edward." 

I think that Miller is right. Time will tell.

passages.name: g38
passages.content:
[Image: rapier] 
We get jumped again, this time by three of the maggotbeasts: but my skeletons manage to hold them down until we have set them on fire. Sadly we also loose my ten skeletons. 

Parker raises an eyebrow: "Bruja, eh? Who would have thought that a posh girl like you has learned the black arts of the Haitiian slaves before she became a whore?" Well, I guess he has met a Bruja. Or mambo. The ones sold as slaves sometimes ...turn sour... and do their black arts with both the living and the dead. Back in Africa they usually make living zombies.

Miller shrugs: "Marston Manor is in the Cornish hills, Parker. That is also an old country. Roman ruins, right behind the skullery. With deep catacombs that the twins liked to play in." I blink and sigh: I may have been a little unsubtle as a child, and Marcella following my steps has not helpded. But those ruins are not Roman, not the oldest, deepest parts. 
Marcella COULD have learned a lot about magic down there, but she was a child. I was, well: reborn as a child. Big difference...

We turn around another corner in the ancient Incam walls, and stand before a pyramid. 
Waiting for us are Sir Edward, Mendoza, Sir WIlliam and Marcellus. 
Teniente Fontana and Mr. Jones are lying on the stone plates, bound and blindfolded.

passages.name: g39
passages.content:
Sir Edward smiles. "Welcome. You took your sweat time, young ...is it 'whore' or 'donna'? Or both?" 

Sir William nods at Miller. Miller tales the blindfolds off Teniente Fontana and Mr. Jones and walks over to the  side of Sir WIlliam. Parker looks at the two groups, shrugs and walks over to Sir Edward's side. Mendoza growls, quite unlike a rational human being. Well: a rational or a human being. 
[Image: standoff]
I smile and blast Mendoza into green slime on the pyramid wall. I raise an eyebrow: "While we are exchanging pawns... Does this count as a sacrifice? After all the Great Maggot One down in that pit had already gotten to Mendoza. Impressive: he was the only one with a maggot as a heart that could behave -remotely- like a living human being." 

Sir Edward smirks: "Daring, little whore. But let us not speak of sacrifices. Let us talk about chances. This is an old ruin. Once there were monsters: but you have destroyed all of these ...let us call them maggot-men. I promise that there are none left. What IS left are the old wards. GOLDEN wards. I suggest that we take the gold and get out of here. 
If you are with us, little whore: welcome. If not, we can dispose of anypne who does not like this by kicking them down that pit." He looks at the prisoners: "Teniente ... Mr. Jones. You both get the same offer. AND a boon: the first one of you to join us gets to keep the whore. I know that you both want her." 

I shrug: "I would hate to free the prisoner down in the pit. Because all these gold wards keep the very being inside that TURNED Spanish conquistadores into fat sucking monsters in the first place." 

Sir WIlliam  pats his leg with his right hand -at the side, where Sir Edwad cannot see it, and shows Marcellus and Miller his middle finger. Miller shoots Sir Edward in the head.

passages.name: Mendozza
passages.content:
Mendoza -that is "Senor de Mendoza" to foreigners- is of average height, with dark hair, a dark moustache and pale, bad skin. 

Other than being ugly he is also not talking all that much. Not at all, in fact. He barely behaves like a servant should: some gentlemen have better trained pets. 

That would probably be the impression of a human debutante. 
To me he looks hungry, angry and desperate. 

He is no Dark One Hybrid -those look like a cross of humans and frogs- and he is not one of our bastards: he smells wrong. Not that my sense of smell is any good in a human body. 

But he is something or other. 
[Image: sword]
He carries an old sword, probably dating back from the original Spanish conquistarodes. Well, they left some of those on the ground: most of them died screaming in this brave new world that they thought to conquer.

passages.name: sirwilliam2
passages.content:
Sir William wants to be magnanimous, charming and patriotic. One politician said: "diplomats are men send abroad to lie for the benefit of their countres". A diplomat answered: "politicians do not travel". 

Father travels well: if anything he has lost some surplus weight. If there was another debutante in the room she would take one look around and hone in on him. Sir William is a widower with two grown children. If he married again his wife would not HAVE to lie back and think of England a lot. He is a middle aged gentleman, not a young stud, after all. Even the ladies that actually LIKE thinking of England have to worry with younger, hungrier husbands: giving birth is dangerous.  Sir Williams is also comfortably rich and fit enough to go to parties for another three decades if all goes well. 

Sadly the only debutantes are Marcella -who is using my body because she hates being a debutante- and me: and I am not really a girl. Not that incest is acceptable in human society. 

As it is, Sir William just has dinner and endure both Sir Edwards occasional rantings and Parker's rude comments. 
Life can be hard for a gentleman.

passages.name: g26
passages.content:
The capitan and the "revolutionary" soldier cheer when the whore shows them the goods. 

[<img[rosa]]Then the captian pushes my backwards, the two soldiers at the third table grab my arms and hold me down. Then the capitan motions the waitress: "Get that woman out of these unseemly, manly clothes." 

The waitress grins and pulls my boots, my pants and my drawers down. She drops my clothes on the floor and sneers: "This may feel a little more drafty than trousers. But based on what you are showing on this table right now I do think that you really are no man, MISS."

The whore with the goods out in the air sneers back: "No, but based on how well you know the difference and based on the way SHE is wriggling on that table I think that SHE is the only cunt in here that still has her cherry." 
She points at the waitress: "When I lost my cherry I was put to work on my rear: why are YOU still waiting tables? You should be with US, you strumpet!" 

Everyone stares at the two ...sisters, obviously: other than the teniente. HE is listening. Then he smiles. 

He steps forward: "Capitan, if I may have a word. Whores will be whores: whether they are on the table, clean tables or show everyone their wares." 

The soldiers holler. I am positive that looks cannot kill: the showy whore, the waitress and I all try to kill the teniente with our looks, but he is perfectly healthy for the moment.

passages.name: g27
passages.content:
The captan laughs: "Let us talk, teniente." The whore drops her dress and sulks, the waitress tries  to get to the counter -closer to the backdoor- and I cannot move with two soldiers holding my arms and my powers gone. 

The teniente comes to the table and lifts my poncho. I close my legs and pull my knees up to block him: I cannot to more at this point.The teniente holds onto my naked legs: "I assume that you are part of the Bolivian Liberation Army. It is well known that this army is offering enlisted men to join them. That is probably why my men..." -he looks at the two dragoons in the corners- "...have betrayed me." 

The capitan nods, and the teniente pushes my legs apart. I try to wiggle out, but the two soldiers ar holding me down. 
The teniente sighs: "But you are not offering the same to officers, are you?" 

The capitan grins and shakes his head. "No, senor teniente. We shoot the officers." 

The teniente pulls me up; one of the soliders takes the hint and grabs my poncho. They also take my blouse and my chemise. The teniente looks down at my naked body: displayed in everyone's full view on that table: "Capitan, I am a cavalrist. I would like to ride a last attack before I must die." 

I try to get free, but they are holding my arms. The capitan laugh and nods, and [[the teniente mounts me like a mare, right on the table, in front of everyone.|g28][$tenienterage to 0; $tenientesexy += 2; $jonessexy to 0; $tits += 2; $creampie += 1; $sidebar to 5]] 
[Image: lted]

passages.name: g24
passages.content:
[Image: cantinaIII]The teniente frowns: "How do you know my name, capitan? Military intelligence is one thing, but knowing the name of the enemy commander...." 

The capitan sneers: "Well, actually you have a traitor in your ranks." He points at the dragoons in the corner: "Two of them, in fact. One has told me your route, your name and that you would accompany the foreigners with two men. The other did not tell me your name, but he did tell me that the rest of your half squadron would follow you and meet you here." 

The dragoons are both nervous: maybe the capitan is telling the truth. I should be able to discern that, but I should also be able to cast spells. Someone -soneONE with real power- has stolen mine. 
The teniente is not the only one who is being betrayed: Sir William and Marcellus are betraying me. 
Why? 
Because Marcella used to be a girl and humans have silly rules about heritage?! 

I will discuss that at length with them once this is over and I have regained my powers.

passages.name: g25
passages.content:
The capitan disturbs my line of thoughts by slapping me in the face: "I said: WHY ARE YOU WEARING A MAN'S CLOTHES?!" 

[Image: poncho]What? I blink: "Women wear a skirt or a dress. I am wearing an article of cloth that covers my body from my shoulders to my knwees. That article of clothing..." -what the locals call a 'poncho'- "...fullfills all requirements to female attire..." 

The capitan slaps me again: "I was not asking about the poncho. I was asking why you are wearing breeches. Drop them! Now! Those are a man's clothes!" 

I frown and snap my fan open: "As an officer and gentleman you positively cannot ask a lady to undo clothes in public."

The capitan blinks, then he shrugs: "You are telling me that you poncho is a dress. If a woman wears a dress, lady or whore, she is dressed completely." 

I snap my fan shut with a snap: "No lady is dressed only wearing her dress." Seeing that the dreses in fashion are thin silk things that require at least a chemise and underskirts, no one could argue that. 

The captian snorts and points at the whores: "They are dressed, are they not? One silver peso for the one who proves that women can be dressed wearing nothing but a dress!" He seems to actually know what these whores are wearing or not wearing...

There may be honour among thieves, but whores in a cantina are mean. One of them jumps up and shows everyone her tits and bush: By raising her dress.

passages.name: g22
passages.content:
[Image: cantinaII]The tavernkeeper keeps polishing a mug, the waitress keeps cleaning a table, the whores sit at the wall without so much as a smile. 

The teniente repeats his order. 

The tavernkeeper keeps polishing a mug, the waitress keeps cleaning a table, the whores sit at the wall without so much as a smile. 

The teniente repeats his order and reaches for his pistol. 

The tavernkeeper keeps polishing a mug, the waitress keeps cleaning a table, the whores sit at the wall without so much as a smile. 

I walk to the counter and say in Queche: "Good evening. We need rooms for the night, food and drink for us, and water and hay for our mules and horses." 

The tavernkeeper keeps polishing a mug, the waitress keeps cleaning a table, the whores sit at the wall without so much as a smile. 

What is happening here?!

passages.name: g23
passages.content:
[Image: cantinaIII]Heartbeats before Teniente Fontana blows the brains of the tavernkeeper all over the wall the door opens, and a line of soldiers enter: NOT royal soldiers, though. 

A large man with a big moustache and the epaulettes of a captain leads ten soldiers into the cantina. The capitan stands with the teniente, the ten soldiers sit at the three tables. 

Sir Edward, Mendoza and Parker are still standing at the right wall. The dragoons are in the corners. Miller, Alyce, Sir William and Marcellus are on the left wall. So are the whores. 
 
While they walk in, Marcellus sneers and burns a piece of paper in one of the oil lamps at the wall. My knees buckle, because for the first time in ages all of my powers are gone. Like water in the dessert. Sir William and Marcellus smile at me. 
Miller and Alyce are watching the soldiers: they have probably not nocticed any of this. 

The capitan smiles when the tavernkeeper pours him a tequilla: "Viva la revolution! Gentlemen, men and whores: my name is Capitan Jose Perola. I represent the liberated Bolivia. Please note that I have ten men under arms in this cantina. 

The rest of my squadron is right now assaulting the half squadron of dragoons that are following Teniente Fonatana and the British gentlemen." He turns to the teniente: "How nasty of you to have these people followed. Planning to waylay them, eh?" 

I do not like the way he is talking.

passages.name: g20
passages.content:
[Image: village]We ride for another couple of hours and reach a small village. 

When the peasants see a group of armed men (and two women) with three royal dragoons leading them they hurry into their houses and lock everything: bolting doors and window shutters. 

The only noises come from our group and the village well, that is powered by wind blades in the village square. Other than the well there is also a church at one end of the square and an inn on the other end. 

At the long side of the square, between church and inn, are metal rings in the walls where we bind our mules ...and the huge horses of the cavalrists. 

Sir Larkin smiles thinly at me and Alyce and tells Sir WIlliam: "You have insisted in bringing your daughter and a maid. For educational purposes, I assume. Well, tonight they will learn aboutt the kind of inn that operates in a village like that." 

Marcellus frowns: "What kind of inn would that be, Sir Edward?!" 

Sir Edward sneers: "These inns are multi-purpose. They are also the stores where the villagers buy goods. All else: well, take a look. This is the only place where we -and your fair sister- can spend the night anyhow." 

Sir William shrugs: "Enough. It is what it is. Let's move."  

Apropos learning: I can go to the church (with Alyce) or head to the cantina with the men..

passages.name: g21
passages.content:
[Image: cantina]When we enter the cantina, the villagers get up and walk out. They do not finish their meals or drinks, they do not speak a single word. They just stand up and walk. 

Only the tavernkeeper, a waitress and five whores remain in the cantina. The low, windowless room is lit by small oil lights: one on every table and some more hanging from the walls. 

One of the younger whores and the waitress look like the tavernkeeper and the oldest whore. Everyone looks unhappy: but that is probably because of us. 

The whores and the waitress -she is wearing a white blouse and dark skirts, the whores are wearing bright, 'airy' dresses- do not look haggard, and none of them shows signs of recent beatings. They are quite possible as happy as villagers like them can be. 

The teniente signals his men, and they take position in the corners left and right to the door. He looks at the whore at the wall, then at me and Alyce. I raise an eyebrow, and he turns away. 

He walks to the counter and orders "Food and tequilla" for him and his men.

passages.content:
Marcellus is very proud about his charm, his sword and his penis.

I need to look after her ...him.

He stops, all inside me: "Well, well. She really WAS a virgin. Well: we all know the diference between a virgin and a whore. Virgins do not get fucked on the table of a brothel. This one is a whore now, just like all the others."

passages.name: g29
passages.content:
The door and the backdoor of the cantina are kicked open and a horde of dragoons charges in: pistols and sabres in hand. The revolutionaries are slow to turn from the sight of me getting deflowered on the table, and before they can drawn their weapons all is over.

His real name MOST assuredly is not 'Mike the Fountain'.

The dragoon salutes: "We were camping at the designated area when we were attacked from both sides. After a moment I realized that we were under attack from not one but TWO parties, one of them these men..." -he points at the dead soldier- "...and a group of ...madmen. These guys were good at sneaking, but your orders were very explicit, and we had set up camp accordingly. Lots of blackpowder bombs around the camp." 

He looks at Milleer: "That one knows what I am talking about: they are having some of these bombs in their saddlebags." He turns back to the teniente: "The madmen and these men also fought each other, and we were the only ones wearing armour. We lost half a dozen good men, sir: but we -and the madmen- have killed fourty of these guys, and we have killed some of the madmen." 

He hesitates: "The bodies of the madmen have burned in the fires from the bombs and the blunderbusses, sir. We have burried the enemy, but we did not have found any of the madmen's bodies. Just their ashes." 

He shrugs: "Then we have come here. Killed the two guards in the square and witnessed our teniente breaking in a pretty mare: a hard and well done ride, if I may say so." 

The teniente nods: "Good fighting, men. But get guards out, sagento. We had an easy victory here because I managed to distract the enemy with the defloration of this littl

passages.name: Sir William
passages.content:
Sir William Marston is a gentleman, diplomat and widower with two -twin- children. That is his public face, and that is very much who he wants to be. He is charming, long suffering and less of a pushover than some lower-class people believe: to their misfortune if they try something that Sir WIlliam does not tolerate. 

He is also the father of Macellus/Marcella and me. 

As a diplomat he serves the parliament, as a gentleman he feels loyal to the king (and his regent: the king is a child). Both affiliations work together quite well: the main, shared enemies are 
- the French (handled aptly by Nelson and Wellington), 
- the seperatists and other colonials (not really handled at all) 
and 
- the East India Compaany that was quite close to taking over the realm completely. 

At the moment the Royalists and the parliament block are trying to move slowly and carefully against the Company, never really declaring war on them and at least pretending to work with them. 

That is why father is hosting Sir Edward and Prker: but that is also why Mr. Jones and Miller are at the table. Just in case...

passages.name: jones2
passages.content:
Mr. Jones is either charming with me and witty with Marcellus or the other way round. Or both. 

I like wit -if good natured- and enjoy the company of Mr. Jones. Marcellus is not sure about the intentions of the good gentleman and unsure whether he likes anyone having intentions about him or his body. 

Mr. Jones is of marrying age, so flirting with debutantes comes natural, I guess. I have no idea whether he is looking for a wife, of course. If so, he would aks Sir William for Marcella's hand: none of my business. 

But probably he is just being charming and witty. 

Mr. Jones is ...working for King and Parliament, like Sir William. I am not entirely sure whether they work the same angle: maybe Sir WIlliam is more parliament and Mr. Jones is more crown. But this is not the 11th century when the barons blackmailed King John Lackland into the Magna Carte. Here and now they share a common enemy (at home): the East India Company. 

There is no danger of Sir William marrying Marcella off as a peacemaking gesture.

passages.name: Sir Edward
passages.content:
Sir Edward Larkin is taller than average -probabyl as tall as Mr. Jones, if Sir Edward would stand straight- and lean. He looks unhealthy and had trouble standing remotely straight. 

Nonetheless he is the one who has come up with the idea for this expedition. He cannot be denied being part of the travelling group because he has the diary of the old conquistador and his map. Sir Edward also cannot be denied becaue he is the local ...envoy... of the East India Company: his bad health nonewithstanding. 

The East India Company worships money and worldly power like a cultist worships a Great Old One: committing heinous crimes in the self-assured knowledge to be the chosen of the one thing/monstrous god that counts. 

Nonetheless Sir Edward is a gentleman, and goes through the motions of being polite. Parker and he do not get along, but Mendoza is Sir Edward's man ...if Mendoza is anything. 

Sir Edwards uttlerly ignores most people, including Marcellus and me.

passages.name: f34
passages.content:
The padre looks down at me. "You are not the first bride to faint, senora. Especially if the bride is as far from being a virgin as you are. But usually brides faint when they and their bastards are left waiting at the altar, not after the ring is put on their finger." Weird words from a padre. If he really is one...

[Image: ring]I look at my wedding band. I smile when I get to study my 'wedding band' in detail.. 
This is a ward against the Liar, The Soul And Messenger Of The Outer Gods. For some reason -maybe to keep entertained- that one has to follow some rules. One of these rules is: wear this sign and you are not beholden by That One. 
Since I am not beholden by him, I am free from the enchantment put on me in His name. My powers are back. 

I get up in a fluid motion, and raise an eyebrow: "Silly me. Where is the briedemaid?" 

One of the dragoons points at her: she is wearing clothes and standing, on her feet. That is not ALL bad, right? 
Alyce is alive and wearing clothes for a change. She seems to hate me less than this morning. Seething rather than boiling hate: she had to take much abuse herself while I only had to lay with the teniente.. 

The padre shrugs: "Care as I do about the fate of heretic whores, there are more problems. We have been beset by monsters several times while you were unconscious, and the expedition group is missing. The British mercenary tells me that YOU of all people may be useful in this situation." 

I look around. "Who is part of the expedition group? And why are you NOT part of it?" 

The padre shrugs: "The teniente has taken Sir William, Sir Edward, Mr. Marston, Mr. Jones and that Mendoza person as well as five dragoons. I am not part of that group because I am the only one that can draw the wards that -together with the bravery of our dragoons- keep this camp from being overrun." 

I nod: "Who is there to go into the temple with me?" 
Miller and Parker.

passages.content:
The horsetrader nods: "Ten silver it is. Unless you want soms lamas or alpaccas rather than mules. Mules are hardier and but also more expensive." 

I blink and shake my head: alpaccas HATE us. I have utterly no idea how they now what I am - I really smell like a human- but they always recognize me and HATE me.

But you are pretty, and bad things happen to pretty senoritas in the counrtyside. If you come back with a changed attitude and, well: broken in ...I would be interested in offering you a place in my other stables. I also hire out the other kinde of mares." 
He slaps my rear: "I never break them in. I only take whores. But you are not back yet, so there is still hope for you, pretty senorita. The difference between a whore and a senorita is gone with the first thrust, you know. Maybe, when we will meet again, you will be ...opened for my offer." 

I raise an eyebrow and walk out. We still need these mules, and if he is wrong nothing will come out of this...

passages.content:
Sir William raises an eyebrow: "There seems to be a slight misunderstanding. I am not here to GAIN magical power. I am here to get rdid of a magically empowered enemy." 

I raise an eyebrow and ask in Latin: "Do you insist, William?"  

Sir William sighs and answers in kind: "No, not really. I was not aware that you are relatively ...restrained. 
But you have not done that..." -he points at the green smear that was Mendoua- "...to any human being, and you are not attacking me and mine blindly even though I have declared myself in public." 
He points at dead body of Sir Edward and the green smear that was Mendoza and adds in English: "I guess that this is the REAL enemy. Monsters made by thing like the one down in that pit; and those that want to free it. 
I still think that YOU are a monster, old friend. But nonetheless you are a monster that makes and keeps treaties. 
THESE monsters and their servants do not parley. We have to choose our enemies, I guess. 
What about a cessefire? You cannot possibly return to Britain as a whore, can you?"

I raise an eyebrow: "I got happy news for you, father. I got married. I do not mind a mutual pact of non-aggression, as long as we seperate fortunes and you do not intervene with me going where I want to be. Oh: and I want Marston Manor as my dowry. You are not using it anymore, and that is a very small compensation for your betrayal." 

Sir William shrugs: "Done. You get Marston Manor and the money that you have put up for my daughter's dowry: only fitting since you ARE my daughter now." 

I would LIKE to kill him and Macellus, but I am too old to kill all my enemies.

passages.name: g41
passages.content:
Parker raises an eyebrow: "Heart-warming. All this talk about betrayal and all that makes me swoon with happiness. There is still the matter of GOLD:" 

I shrug: "Miller, please throw one of your bombs down there. Set to explode after a drop of twelve yards if you can do that." 

Miller looks at Sir William, who nods. When the barrel full of blackpowder and nails explodes, something down their screetches. 

I turn to Parker: "You can set that free. You will get about 20 pounds of gold and a worm inside your chest that makes you one of the fat-sucking man-maggots. You will also be one of MANY since the maggot down there will be free to crawl the lang. Interested?"
